discourse_list.title: NFT LP tokens on Uniswap v3 - consequences for Maker

content.content: In their latest blog post, Uniswap have indicated that their LP tokens will become non-fungible tokens. Does this affect Maker’s ability to use them as collateral for vaults and generate DAI from them? An earlier discussion on NFT vaults is here but that was focussed more on the artistic NFTs, whose value is a little harder to estimate.
content.GPT-summary: The post discusses the potential consequences of Uniswap's decision to make their LP tokens non-fungible tokens on Maker's ability to use them as collateral for vaults and generate DAI from them. The author asks if this decision will affect Maker and if there is any previous discussion on NFT vaults. The post is a question and review of the potential impact of Uniswap's decision on Maker's operations.

content.content: Since liquidity can be provisioned across any custom distribution, LP positions are non-fungible. In short, yes this has a huge impact on our ability to use them as collateral. That being said it’s not impossible just non-trivial. Ideally Uniswap would create a token wrapper around “common” LP distributions which would chunk large amounts of liquidity into fungible pieces. These V3 LP tokens could then be used as collateral within Maker. A Uniswap created solution is likely to become a standard which increases composability and liquidity. Absent of an official “blessed” token wrapper, either Maker, Aave, or a yield-aggregator like Yearn could step in to create these wrappers with the risk that others create competing standards and integrations/liquidity becomes fragmented.

content.content: Would it make any kind of sense to industrialize vault types by deploying once an audited UNIv3-LP-Vault-Factory, derive oracles from a single source using each NFT’s parameters, and… somehow magically deal with liquidations? Not that it would be a good idea either way but I’m curious about feasibility.
